topics: The first part of the project (ENVE400) will include problem identification, generation and selection of solutions, and time management.
A basic requirement of the proposed solution is that it must be compatible with the principles of sustainability.

The purpose of the project is to demonstrate students' abilities to practise in a geological engineering capacity in their chosen area of expertise, using knowledge gained from their academic and employment experiences.
A basic requirement of the proposed solution is that it must be compatible with the principles of sustainability.
Introduction
Design Process
Alternative Evaluation
Progress Meeting Expectations
Sustainability considerations must be central to the proposed project.
While research (i.e., discovery of new knowledge) may be an important component of engineering design, research-only projects are not appropriate for Engineering Capstone Design Projects.
A five-person team will require a special plan to do more work than the normal four person teams.
Each design team will choose an appropriate Environmental/Geological engineering problem that reflects the interests of the team members.
Teams must select a challenging design problem.
A challenging problem is one where you have few, if any, alternative designs in mind to start the project.
Outstanding grades are possible even if you can’t demonstrate clear innovation in the projects.
Teams must demonstrate that a range of design alternatives were considered.
Teams must quantitatively evaluate multiple alternatives and multiple design objectives/constraints (e.g., engineering analysis and engineering decision-making).

The standard project will demonstrate this alternative generation and decision-making in this 400 course, however, in some projects, it could be more natural to save the alternative generation and decision-making application to the next term (in 401).
Such an arrangement must be approved on a case-by-case basis by Professor Tolson who may choose to consult with your technical advisor.
Project managers are not exempt from participating in the technical aspects of the project, but their time commitment to these aspects will be reduced.
The project manager responsibilities include:
keeping their team on track and constructively motivate other team members,
Instructors will also provide critical comments and motivate students to do the best job they can.

Please consider that the personal traits and habits that you develop during your education are carried forward into your career.

course_name: AE573 - HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.
2. Explain operational characteristics of selected energy-saving strategies for HVAC systems.
3. Assess the potential for selected energy-saving strategies to operate effectively for a variety of operating conditions and applications.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Industrial Ecology Fall 2024

Industrial ecology is a rapidly growing field that systematically examines local, regional, and global uses and flows of materials and energy in products, processes, industrial sectors, and economies.

It focuses on the potential role of industry in reducing environmental burdens throughout the product life cycle from the extraction of raw materials to the production of goods, to the use of those goods and to the management of the resulting wastes.
This course will review the environmental issues associated with chemical industries and the roles of engineers to manage these issues.
The principles and philosophy of green chemistry will be addressed including pollution prevention in unit operations.
The concepts and practices of environmental life cycle analysis and accounting will be addressed in detail, together with the basics of risk assessment, management and communication.

Graduate Attribute Program Indicators

A knowledge base for engineering: Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
1a Demonstrate understanding of concepts in mathematics.
1b Demonstrate understanding of concepts in natural science.
1c Demonstrate understanding of engineering fundamentals.
1d Demonstrate understanding of specialized engineering knowledge.
2. Problem Analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

3. Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.
3a Create investigative studies of complex engineering problems.
3b Gather information from relevant sources to address complex engineering problems.

4. Design: An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
4a Define design requirements and specifications for complex, open-ended engineering problems.
4b Critically evaluate and compare design choices.
7. Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.
Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
8a Articulate the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society with reference to the protection of the public and its interest.
Impact of Engineering: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such abilities include an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society; the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.
Analyze the social, health, safety, and environmental aspects of an engineering project, incorporating sustainability considerations and environmental stewardship in making decisions.
10a Identify ethical and unethical behavior in professional situations.
10b Identify how an engineer is accountable to multiple stakeholders in engineering practice.
Life-long Learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world to sufficiently maintain their competence and contribute to the advancement of knowledge.
12a Identify gaps in their knowledge, skills and abilities.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
HVAC Systems, Equipment, and Energy Efficiency Winter 2025
Selected topics in HVAC systems design with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability.
Heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems.
Constant- and variable-flow systems.
Heat- and energy-recovery systems.
Vapour-compression refrigeration and heat-pump systems (including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps).

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Complex Systems Winter 2025
Professor Paul Fieguth pfieguth@uwaterloo.ca Office Hours: Mondays 4-5pm in E7-6338

The overwhelming majority of societal, ecological and climate issues of pressing importance are complex systems; nonlinear dynamic interacting systems poorly characterized by linear analyses and Gaussian statistics.
This course introduces the mathematics needed to understand such interactions, including nonlinear dynamics, critical and bifurcation behaviours, large-scale systems and power-law distributions.

The mathematical methods will be motivated by extensive examples and case studies such as global warming, energy shortages, desertification, overpopulation, poverty, and economic instability, to be investigated from a systems engineering perspective that will connect mathematical concepts to real-world examples.
Understand the assumptions and limitations behind linear dynamic / Gaussian systems
Understand the mathematical properties of nonlinear dynamic / power-law systems
Be able to abstract / generalize the impacts and implications of nonlinear systems
Be able to draw connections between macroscopic socio-environmental systems

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Transit Planning and Operations Winter 2025
The historical evolution of transit in cities; the technological innovations which made transit possible; and transit mode definitions.
System operational characteristics are defined and quantitative measures of effectiveness are introduced.
Methods for selecting appropriate transit modes are covered.
The focus of this course is on the use of quantitative techniques to analyse and solve problems arising in the planning, design, operation and management of urban public transportation systems.

Topics include an introduction to public transportation modes, transit performance analysis, fleet sizing and route design; control of transit operations, and paratransit planning, scheduling and dispatching.

The course also covers various transit modelling issues arising in the Advanced Public Transportation Systems that aim at maximising transit system efficiency and reliability using emerging technologies such as global positioning systems (GPS), electronic fare payment, and automatic passenger counters and pre-trip/en-route passenger information systems.

course_name: EARTH439 - Flow and Transport Through Fractured Rocks (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Email:

Fractures are ubiquitous in geologic media and important in disciplines such as physical and contaminant hydrogeology, geotechnical engineering, civil and environmental engineering, and petroleum engineering among other areas.
Despite the importance of fractures, its characterization and predictions of groundwater flow and contaminant transport are fraught with significant difficulties.
An introduction to the physical hydrogeology of fractured rock.

Topics will include a review of the structural geology of fractured rocks, development and validity of the cubic law, groundwater flow and contaminant transport in discrete fractures and fracture networks, hydraulic testing methods and the hydrogeology of low-permeability environments.
The overall aim for this course is for students to better understand concepts/processes that affect fluid flow and solute transport processes in fractured geologic media.
This includes the proper formulation of conceptual models, its proper translation to mathematical models and to obtain some knowledge on solution techniques to obtain quantitative solutions.
Week No. 6: Analysis of single-hole hydraulic tests in fractured rocks and its implications (Feb. 12), Review (Feb. 14)

topics: Numerical Methods in Hydrogeology Winter 2025
An introduction to the theory and practice of groundwater flow and contaminant transport modeling.

Topics related to variably-saturated flow will focus on derivation of Richard's equation, a control volume finite difference discretization, assembly and solution of the flow equation, material balance error, truncation error analysis, stability and monotonicity.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: DWE 3518
DWE 3518

Types of contaminants; transport phenomena with a focus on advection-dispersive transport; development of governing equations; types and utility of boundary and initial conditions; and mass balance considerations.
Review of completely mixed systems including lakes, streams, source functions, feedback systems, and toxic substance models.
Model calibration, sensitivity, and uncertainty; methods and approaches.
Solute transport models and solution techniques including random walk, method of characteristics, finite difference method and finite volume method.
Introduction to mass removal technologies for remediation of soil and groundwater systems.
One of the key responsibilities of the environmental engineering profession is to monitor, assess, and clean up environmental contamination in the soil, water, and air.

Engineers are tasked to develop, implement, and design technology and best management practices to mitigate contamination, interpret uncertain environmental data to determine the source(s) and or fate of environmental contaminants, and make predictions about how past and future pollution may pose a health threat to humans and ecosystems.
The objective of this course is to introduce you to theoretical and practical aspects of mass transport in natural environmental systems, and to learn how to model mass transport processes.
describe various types of contaminants and their behaviour in a variety of media

formulate and apply a mathematical mass transport model in response to an environmental problem statement (i.e., select appropriate ICs & BCs, recognize appropriate processes to include, and solve the problem using appropriate mathematical methods)
explain the physics and mathematical treatment of key transport processes and be able to distinguish and prioritize their role in the transport and remediation of contaminants
justify the use of assumptions used in contaminant transport models
interpret observation data in conjunction with model results and critically evaluate model results subject to (often significant) uncertainty
To satisfy the above outcomes, you will hone your programming skills, a necessary tool for solving the types of problems addressed in this course.

An introduction to the fundamental processes governing climate and hydrological systems and the links between them.
It starts with a discussion of basic atmospheric and hydrological processes and traces the flow of energy and water between the earth's surface and the atmosphere.
This course provides students with a thorough background of the fundamental processes governing the climate and hydrological systems, and the links between them.
The course first reviews fundamental atmospheric and hydrologic processes, and traces the flow of energy and water between the Earth’s surface and the atmosphere.
Through the use of group activities students will be given the opportunity to gain experience manipulating real hydrological and meteorological data and instrumentation.

The fundamental knowledge and skills developed in this course will provide students with the basis to appreciate and understand the natural hydrologic and climate systems.
It also provides the required foundation for advanced courses in climatology and hydrology.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.
To understand basic fluvial geomorphic processes and their role in landform development and change

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Advanced Remote Sensing Techniques Winter 2025
Advanced image processing techniques of digital remote sensing measurements (e.g. radar systems, optical and infrared systems) from ground, aircraft and satellite instrument systems.
It is used for global environmental change studies and for more local scale applications such as urban landscape mapping, precision farming and hazard mapping.
This course introduces and develops student understanding and skill at using remote sensing information extraction techniques to provide information about human and physical environments.
The course builds on the fundamentals of remote sensing science and Earth observation systems (e.g. visible-infrared and microwave satellite and airborne observing systems) introduced in GEOG271.

It focuses on current information extraction approaches, such as image enhancement and transformations, classification / pattern recognition techniques (including machine learning), and geospatial statistics models, along with accuracy assessment to evaluate retrieved information quality.
The methods are presented and explored using active and passive remote sensing systems.
This course focuses on the use of remote sensing to map key environmental states.
Emphasis is placed on the application of remote sensing methods and data processing for analysis of physical and human environments.
The course presents advanced techniques for further remote sensing and Earth observation work and gives the student a strong basis from which to develop their analytical skills.
understand different satellite and airborne remote sensing observation approaches to monitoring and mapping the Earth surface
be able to apply judiciously a range of information extraction methods to create knowledge about specific Earth environments.
These methods include image transformations, classification/pattern recognition and geospatial models; classification/pattern recognition and geospatial models
be able to evaluate quantitatively the error/uncertainty about the information created from the remote sensing extraction methods and reflect critically on the procedures adopted
master the use of industry-standard remote sensing software (PCI Geomatica) for information extraction and also develop their applied skills
understand of the applicability and limitations of remote sensing information for knowledge creation and to critically reflect on how this information can be used for environmental management

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Energy Conversion Fall 2024
Design of fossil-fuel central power plants, including boiler efficiency calculations and advanced steam and binary cycles.
Review of atomic physics including fission and fusion energy.
Design of nuclear fission power plants including design of reactor core for critical conditions, fuel cycles and radiation hazards.
Design considerations for solar energy conversion devices including: availability of solar energy, solar-thermal converters, thermal storage and photovoltaics.
Principles of fuel cells and some aspects of their design.
We look at the way Canada, and the world, use energy, where the energy comes from, the finite nature of some reserves, and the impact of this energy use on the environment.
Sustainability and the security of energy supply are also discussed.
We review conventional energy systems from an efficiency and global warming perspective.
From the study of these various factors, it will become clear that new energy technologies will need to be adopted in the future.

We then study energy conversion devices and systems not studied in previous courses: for example, nuclear reactors, MHD, fuel cells, solar energy conversion(s), wind energy conversion, co-generation, hydroelectricity, ethanol, methanol, geothermal, ocean thermal, wave, tidal, thermoelectric.
The objective is to broaden the students’ understanding of energy, both in a technical sense and in an environmental and socio-economic sense.

Students must research in depth one topic in energy conversion and present their findings in a 7500 - 10000 word or so (~15-20 pages, … … or so) report.

To select a topic, send me an email request, with alternatives in case your primary request is taken.

However, the socio-economic and environmental aspects of the topic, and some indication of the magnitude of its possible impact on the demand for energy and on global-warming should also be considered.

major_name: Environmental Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Transit Planning and Operations Winter 2025
The historical evolution of transit in cities; the technological innovations which made transit possible; and transit mode definitions.
System operational characteristics are defined and quantitative measures of effectiveness are introduced.
Methods for selecting appropriate transit modes are covered.
The focus of this course is on the use of quantitative techniques to analyse and solve problems arising in the planning, design, operation and management of urban public transportation systems.

Topics include an introduction to public transportation modes, transit performance analysis, fleet sizing and route design; control of transit operations, and paratransit planning, scheduling and dispatching.

The course also covers various transit modelling issues arising in the Advanced Public Transportation Systems that aim at maximising transit system efficiency and reliability using emerging technologies such as global positioning systems (GPS), electronic fare payment, and automatic passenger counters and pre-trip/en-route passenger information systems.

Focus will be applied to the adaptive strategies employed by algae to move from water to land, the development of complex tissues and organs and the role of reproduction strategies in plant success.
Cellular composition of plant tissues and what role they play in their function will be studied; with particular interest in the relationship between vascular tissue and water transport.

Additionally, students will study how hormones and growth regulators regulate plant development, tropic movement and plant response to biotic and abiotic stressors, as well as learn of their many uses in agriculture.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Ecosystem Ecology Fall 2024
This course provides an overview of the dynamic interactions among microbes, plants, animals, and their physical environment with emphasis on ecosystem structure and function.

Topics explored through lectures and tutorial sessions include the hydrological cycle, biogeochemical cycling, ecological energetics, roles of population and community interactions, paleoecology, and current topics in ecosystem science.
An ecosystem is defined as an integrated system of interacting biotic and abiotic components that occupy a volume of space.
Consequently, society needs well trained people with skills in ecosystem science to effectively protect and manage ecosystems in the face of ever-growing pressures.
Both theoretical and applied aspects of ecosystem ecology will be discussed.

The synchronous (scheduled) in-person tutorials and associated assignments will provide experiential learning of relevant skills in generation and interpretation of data, integration of concepts, critical analysis, and written and oral communication.
Define and explain, in written and oral presentations, the main terms and concepts in ecosystem ecology, such as energy flow and nutrient cycling.
Explain how interactions between organisms and the environment regulate the structure and function of ecosystems.
Generate, analyze and interpret data on nutrient limitation, nutrient cycling and food-web interactions, and communicate the findings and their importance in written reports.
Use basic principles of ecosystem science to anticipate how ecosystems and their components will likely respond to changes in physical, chemical and biological conditions.
Critically analyze published research papers in ecosystem ecology.

The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

Dr. Rosamond's teaching philosophy focuses on (a) active learning techniques, including field and laboratory experience, and practical demonstrations in class, (b) building on the mathematical and chemical fundamentals in Earth Sciences.

topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrology Fall 2024
This course consists of field exercises and lectures designed to provide students with practical hands-on experience conducting a variety of hydrological monitoring techniques.
This course is designed to provide hands-on field experience in the use of standard hydrologic monitoring techniques.

The main objectives of this course are to use a variety of hydrologic data collection techniques in practical settings to answer hydrologic questions, identify the difficulty and importance of collecting good field data, and determine the accuracy/error of different measurement methods quantitatively and qualitatively.
A Module will consist of two elements: (1) an activity in the field and (2) lecture and tutorial to review the fundamental concepts and discuss the data collected in the field.
During each activity you will be working in groups of ~4.
Assessment for each Module will consist of a pre-activity quiz administered on LEARN and an assignment that must be completed individually and uploaded to LEARN.
Interpret the data in a hydrological context to explain groundwater/surface-water interactions, quantify water balances, and understand sources of contaminants found in water.

The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.

interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Organismal and Evolutionary Ecology Fall 2023
Learn Discussion Board
Email and Appointment Requests

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

The organization of these building blocks into more complex structures such as proteins, enzymes, polynucleotides, polysaccharides, and biological membranes will be described.
The structure and function of representative proteins such as myoglobin and hemoglobin and enzymes such as chymotrypsin will also be discussed.
Applications and importance of the above to real world situations will be provided.

Predict the flow of information from DNA to RNA
Compare the structure and physical properties of lipids and fatty acids, and understand their role in the formation of membrane bilayers
Take all the information learned this term and develop a deeper understanding of the chemical processes that lead to life as we know it

course_name: BIOL439 - Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry Fall 2024
okey.igboeli@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with the functions, distribution, and environmental ramifications of natural compounds produced by plants and other biological systems.

Natural products are those compounds usually described as secondary metabolites, i.e., those apparently non-essential products whose physiological and ecological functions are either obscure or are of peripheral importance to the organism.

However, many of these non-essential products have profound competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance; and as research proceeds, their physiological roles within the parent organisms are becoming clearer.
As well, this course has a strong emphasis on how environmental chemical and physical processes impact on living organisms and their biochemistry.
Describe the importance of physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to plant secondary metabolites.
Integrate physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to different plant secondary metabolites.
Introduction: Products of primary and secondary metabolism.
Importance of secondary metabolites.
Plant-derived pharmaceutical compounds

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Ecology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Methods of Aquatic Ecology Fall 2024

As an active researcher in aquatic ecology for more than 30 years (with the Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Environment Canada, Canadian Water Network and the University of Waterloo) the instructor (Prof. Mark Servos) will highlight and demonstrate some key techniques and share experiences based on extensive field work in Canada and elsewhere.
Professor Mark Servos
An introduction to methods used to sample and characterize the ecological structure and function of aquatic ecosystems, including basic aspects of the abiotic environment.
Field trips to lake and stream sites are combined with laboratory analysis of samples and data.
While the main emphasis is on the techniques, the exercises also provide direct experience with some of the natural and anthropogenic variation observable in aquatic systems.
On-line background with readings and assignments,
Field collections/demonstrations,
Sample preparation, analysis and demonstrations,
The impact of Belwood Lake on the ecology of the Grand River below the Shand Dam is used as a case study.
Students will develop an understanding of the common methods used in aquatic ecology to study and assess biodiversity and change in aquatic ecosystems.
It should be noted that the intention is not to cover every aspect of aquatic ecology but to apply methods and techniques that are common in current biomonitoring program.
Identify and use common sampling equipment applied in aquatic ecology,
Understand the physical and ecological structure and processes of a lake environment,
Understand the physical and ecological structure of a stream environment,
Put the ecological data collected into the context of the physical/biological environment,
Field Trip/Lab
Adaptation to Rivers
Data Analysis and Review
Practical Test and Data Analysis
Freshwater Ecology: Concepts and Environmental Applications in Limnology, 3rd Edition, 2020.
The assignments are all linked to the final interpretation and synthesis of the field sampling data and preparation of the final report.
The first assignments focus on field sampling methods (supporting the field trips) and then analysis of the samples collected and data interpretation.
Practical Test
This will be a test of the acquired skills for field collections, sample preservation, identifications/methods.
You will be issued a field lab book on the first class/lab.

topics: Advanced Geochemistry Fall 2024
Development of the three laws of thermodynamics; Gibbs free energy and equilibria constants.
Introduction to various topics in aqueous geochemistry such as mineral equilibria, ion exchange, and redox equilibria.
View requirements for EARTH 421
Development of the three Laws of Thermodynamics; Gibbs free energy and equilibrium constants.
Introduction to various topics in aqueous geochemistry, such as mineral equilibrium, ion exchange and redox equilibrium.
Laboratory sessions will involve various activities related to acid-base equilibrium, redox reactions, chemical modeling, and analytical instrumentation methods.
Thermodynamics offers Geoscientists a powerful tool to aid in the interpretation of near surface processes.

It can be used to delineate the physicochemical conditions that led to a particular mineral assemblage; to discern whether a mineral assemblage could have resulted from equilibrium or disequilibrium (kinetic-controlled) conditions; to aid in decision-making in exploration geochemistry; and to design geochemical barriers and containment systems at waste disposal sites.
Applications include geothermal systems, acid-mine drainage, carbon sequestration, and other near surface environmental systems.
Develop thermodynamic principles most relevant to geochemical systems
Understand the concepts of chemical equilibrium and metastability in the context of Earth systems
Develop conceptual and empirical models to describe natural geochemical systems
Apply geochemical principles toward achieving a sustainable use of Earth’s resources, including predicting the impacts of resource development and developing strategies for mitigation of impacts
Communicate geochemical concepts to various audiences
Introduction and review
Thermodynamics of Pure Substances
Examples: Steam separation in geothermal systems, CO2 compressibility for sequestration.
Thermodynamics of Simple Mixtures
Free Energy (G)
Determining mineral phase transitions.
The derivation of the equilibrium constant (K) from the first and second laws.
The need for the third law and evidence; where thermodynamic data originates and its limitations
Free energy calculations
Aqueous Solutions
Applications of acid-base and redox reactions in natural and perturbed systems.
Aqueous geochemistry
Solubility products and saturation indices; the influence of ion hydrolysis on mineral and gas solubilities.

The second StoryMap will be about a specific map sheet area selected from a short list of available surficial geology maps produced by a government geological survey in recent years.

The StoryMap will provide an overview of the main geological and geomorphological features of the map, and will also put the map into the broader regional context based on the available scientific literature.

topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrogeology Fall 2024
An introduction to the principles and theories of mineral deposit genesis.
Basic technical, economic, legal, and ethical aspects of mineral exploration and responsible development of natural resources are also covered.
View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.
Labs will be completed in groups with field data recorded in field books or datasheets.
These data will be used to a complete individual lab assignment.
This site contains over 100 groundwater monitoring wells.

(3) Measurement of in-situ hydraulic conductivity using single-well response tests
Each lab will provide you with a unique dataset that you will use to develop a conceptual site model of the local groundwater flow system.
• Properly construct and interpret soil core logs using United Soil Classification System, and make lithostratigraphic interpretations using geophysical logs
• Assess and interpret water level measurements through the construction of water table maps and flownets
• Interpret single-well response tests including falling and rising head (slug) tests to determine in-situ hydraulic conductivity
• Interpret hydraulic pumping tests to determine aquifer transmissivity and storage parameters and assess water resource vulnerability
Each module will contain a series of recorded lecture slides and video demonstrations reviewing core concepts and guidelines for the upcoming field lab.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Organismal and Evolutionary Ecology Fall 2023
Learn Discussion Board
Email and Appointment Requests

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.
The course is intended to provide basic knowledge of the world of microorganisms and consideration of how we study the activities of these small inhabitants of the planet.
The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.
Describe the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and microbial eukaryotes and differentiate between the three domains of microbial life based on key characteristics.
List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: General Chemistry 1 Winter 2025
RCH 101
The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

Philosophy of Teaching

Dr. Rosamond's teaching philosophy focuses on (a) active learning techniques, including field and laboratory experience, and practical demonstrations in class, (b) building on the mathematical and chemical fundamentals in Earth Sciences.
She is interested in adapting curricula to include experiential learning, focus on students' analytical skills, and to scaffold skills and concepts across courses in Earth & Environmental Sciences.

topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrology Fall 2024
This course consists of field exercises and lectures designed to provide students with practical hands-on experience conducting a variety of hydrological monitoring techniques.
This course is designed to provide hands-on field experience in the use of standard hydrologic monitoring techniques.

The main objectives of this course are to use a variety of hydrologic data collection techniques in practical settings to answer hydrologic questions, identify the difficulty and importance of collecting good field data, and determine the accuracy/error of different measurement methods quantitatively and qualitatively.
A Module will consist of two elements: (1) an activity in the field and (2) lecture and tutorial to review the fundamental concepts and discuss the data collected in the field.
During each activity you will be working in groups of ~4.
Assessment for each Module will consist of a pre-activity quiz administered on LEARN and an assignment that must be completed individually and uploaded to LEARN.
Interpret the data in a hydrological context to explain groundwater/surface-water interactions, quantify water balances, and understand sources of contaminants found in water.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: EARTH 436A
EARTH 436A 001
View requirements for EARTH 436A

Thesis Course (Earth 436) provides an opportunity for students to design and conduct independent research under the supervision of a faculty member in the Department of Earth & Environmental Sciences.
In the past years, a number of excellent research projects have been completed leading in some cases to award winning presentations at conferences and publications in peer-reviewed journals.

Students must normally obtain a minimum mark of 75% in Earth 436A to be allowed to register in Earth 436B. For students who enroll in Earth 436A only, the scope of work will involve the selection of a scientific topic of interest, detailed review of several published papers on the subject and the development of a potential research project that would fill a gap in current knowledge on the subject.

In Earth 436B, the remaining activities required to complete the research project are carried out based on the experimental design formulated in Earth 436A. The format and structure of the Final Research Report can be either a conventional thesis document or a journal manuscript.

It involves oral communication either one on one or before groups both large and small and written communication, which involves preparation of maps, charts and 6 narrative reports with personal observations, analyses and reviews of your own new work and that of previous workers.

While most of your work will be technical and reflect scientific rigor, you may be called upon to prepare shorter status and policy briefs for decision-makers, legal summaries and commentaries, mine stakes and resource claim descriptions, and other items, all of which require organized and well-reasoned clear writing.

Students should familiar with and able to do the following at the end of this course: • plan and conduct independent and original research under the guidance of a research advisor • learn how to explore, organize, execute, share and disseminate the results of your own scientific questions and thoughts • acquire new practical research and analytical skills using data either collected by yourself in the field or assembled in the laboratory or information/data collected by someone else (often the faculty advisor) in a research environment that you would not have had a chance to do elsewhere in your program • learn discipline-specific protocols and procedures for addressing scientific questions and procedures and formats for reporting technical information according to discipline or subdiscipline standards • acquire an appreciation for and basic skill level to organize, interpret, and identify relevance of new information and research results • understand how to organize, communicate effectively and clearly disseminate new information to peers and other professionals, both written and orally • know how to undertake self-assessment, and learn how to give and receive constructive review and critique by your peers

Field trips: Four field trips will occur during lecture and lab session hours in September and early October.
The field trips are intended to give an overview of the glacial stratigraphy and sediment-landform assemblages in the region as well as some hands-on experience.
You will be given the opportunity to learn some basic field description/measurement procedures.
Important note: Field trip fees may be charged to cover direct costs of travel (essentially the cost of school bus transportation service).
In-class quizzes: There will be a series of short in-class quizzes (~10-15 min each) throughout the term.
Each team will have to prepare a StoryMap summarizing the field trips and with one particular aspect of the trips highlighted and explained in greater details.
The second StoryMap will be about a specific map sheet area selected from a short list of available surficial geology maps produced by a government geological survey in recent years.

The StoryMap will provide an overview of the main geological and geomorphological features of the map, and will also put the map into the broader regional context based on the available scientific literature.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introductory Algebra for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
Email: jen.nelson@uwaterloo.ca
Topics will be chosen from linear equations, systems of linear equations, linear inequalities, functions, set theory, permutations and combinations, binomial theorem, probability theory.
The course begins with a review of operations with real numbers and fundamental algebra skills.
The solutions of polynomial equations, both linear and quadratic, in one and two variables and their graphical representation are studied.
An extension is made to linear systems with their solutions being expressed both algebraically and graphically.
To solve linear systems, matrices and the associated row reduction strategies are used.
The relationship between exponential functions and logarithmic functions is examined.
The basic properties of logarithms are introduced and used to solve logarithmic and exponential equations.
Various applications involving exponential growth and decay and logarithmic scales are presented.
Concepts in set theory and counting theory support the study of probability theory.
Perform operations with real numbers and algebraic expressions.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including those involving absolute value, and represent the solutions algebraically and graphically.
Solve a system of linear equations using matrix operations, introducing a free variable, or parameter as appropriate.
Solve quadratic equations in one variable.
Recognize that the solutions to a quadratic equation in two variables lie on a curve known as a parabola and analyze the properties of a parabola.
Describe the relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function.
Use the properties of logarithms to solve logarithmic and exponential equations, and to solve problems involving exponential growth and decay, and logarithmic scales.
Use the appropriate symbols and language in set theory to perform set operations, represent sets and subsets using Venn diagrams, and apply the counting principles for sets in real-life situations.

course_name: MATH104 - Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Geoscience Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Introductory Calculus for Arts and Social Science Winter 2025
The major concepts introduced to solve problems are rate of change, optimization, growth and decay, and integration.
This course provides an introduction to the applications of differential and integral calculus in business, the behavioural sciences, and the social sciences.
A special type of limit will give rise to the derivative, the central idea in differential calculus.

The interpretation of the derivative in applications such as rates of change and optimization, where the situations can be modelled by algebraic, exponential, or logarithmic functions, will be examined.
The concepts of the antiderivative and the indefinite integral will be studied.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus will relate the integral to the derivative.
The problem of calculating the area under a curve will lead to the definite integral, a basic concept of integral calculus.
The interpretation of the integral in various applications will be studied.
be able to interpret a limit, given the graph of a function;
evaluate the limit of a function using appropriate techniques;
determine the derivative of polynomial functions using the definition of a derivative;
determine the derivative of algebraic, exponential, and logarithmic functions using the techniques of differentiation;
apply the derivative to determining equations of tangents, graphing functions, solving rate problems, and solving optimization problems;
determine general and unique antiderivatives;
determine the indefinite integral of a function using the techniques of integration;
determine definite integrals; and

topics: Organismal and Evolutionary Ecology Fall 2023
Learn Discussion Board
Email and Appointment Requests

Coverage includes hypothesis testing and the nature of scientific inquiry, basic population genetics, physiological ecology, life histories, dispersal, basic population and community ecology, macroevolution, systematics and classification, as well as functional morphology.
The theory of evolution unites the whole of biology and all living organisms into a coherent body of knowledge, allowing comparisons across all forms of life.
Ecology describes how organisms interact with their environment and each other to create interdependent systems from microscopic to global scales.

These disciplines are fundamentally tied together: evolution is the primary mechanism by which species adapt to their environment; ecological interactions and environmental variability drive natural selection.

You will also carry out simulated lab assignments to test the principles of evolution, design ecological experiments to test alternate hypotheses about the conservation of species and manipulate demographic parameters to test their influence on population growth.
Understand the principles of scientific methodology
Define ecological and evolutionary terms, such as the niche, adaptation, and altruism
Illustrate these mechanisms in the context of course examples
Explain how ecological interactions and evolution are interconnected

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.
The course is intended to provide basic knowledge of the world of microorganisms and consideration of how we study the activities of these small inhabitants of the planet.
The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.
Describe the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and microbial eukaryotes and differentiate between the three domains of microbial life based on key characteristics.
List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

topics: Ecosystem Ecology Fall 2024
This course provides an overview of the dynamic interactions among microbes, plants, animals, and their physical environment with emphasis on ecosystem structure and function.

Topics explored through lectures and tutorial sessions include the hydrological cycle, biogeochemical cycling, ecological energetics, roles of population and community interactions, paleoecology, and current topics in ecosystem science.
An ecosystem is defined as an integrated system of interacting biotic and abiotic components that occupy a volume of space.
Consequently, society needs well trained people with skills in ecosystem science to effectively protect and manage ecosystems in the face of ever-growing pressures.
Both theoretical and applied aspects of ecosystem ecology will be discussed.

The synchronous (scheduled) in-person tutorials and associated assignments will provide experiential learning of relevant skills in generation and interpretation of data, integration of concepts, critical analysis, and written and oral communication.
Define and explain, in written and oral presentations, the main terms and concepts in ecosystem ecology, such as energy flow and nutrient cycling.
Explain how interactions between organisms and the environment regulate the structure and function of ecosystems.
Generate, analyze and interpret data on nutrient limitation, nutrient cycling and food-web interactions, and communicate the findings and their importance in written reports.
Use basic principles of ecosystem science to anticipate how ecosystems and their components will likely respond to changes in physical, chemical and biological conditions.
Critically analyze published research papers in ecosystem ecology.

topics: General Chemistry 1 Winter 2025
RCH 101
The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

Philosophy of Teaching

Dr. Rosamond's teaching philosophy focuses on (a) active learning techniques, including field and laboratory experience, and practical demonstrations in class, (b) building on the mathematical and chemical fundamentals in Earth Sciences.
She is interested in adapting curricula to include experiential learning, focus on students' analytical skills, and to scaffold skills and concepts across courses in Earth & Environmental Sciences.

topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrology Fall 2024
This course consists of field exercises and lectures designed to provide students with practical hands-on experience conducting a variety of hydrological monitoring techniques.
This course is designed to provide hands-on field experience in the use of standard hydrologic monitoring techniques.

The main objectives of this course are to use a variety of hydrologic data collection techniques in practical settings to answer hydrologic questions, identify the difficulty and importance of collecting good field data, and determine the accuracy/error of different measurement methods quantitatively and qualitatively.
A Module will consist of two elements: (1) an activity in the field and (2) lecture and tutorial to review the fundamental concepts and discuss the data collected in the field.
During each activity you will be working in groups of ~4.
Assessment for each Module will consist of a pre-activity quiz administered on LEARN and an assignment that must be completed individually and uploaded to LEARN.
Interpret the data in a hydrological context to explain groundwater/surface-water interactions, quantify water balances, and understand sources of contaminants found in water.

Development of the three Laws of Thermodynamics; Gibbs free energy and equilibrium constants.

Laboratory sessions will involve various activities related to acid-base equilibrium, redox reactions, chemical modeling, and analytical instrumentation methods.
Thermodynamics offers Geoscientists a powerful tool to aid in the interpretation of near surface processes.

It can be used to delineate the physicochemical conditions that led to a particular mineral assemblage; to discern whether a mineral assemblage could have resulted from equilibrium or disequilibrium (kinetic-controlled) conditions; to aid in decision-making in exploration geochemistry; and to design geochemical barriers and containment systems at waste disposal sites.
Applications include geothermal systems, acid-mine drainage, carbon sequestration, and other near surface environmental systems.
Develop thermodynamic principles most relevant to geochemical systems
Understand the concepts of chemical equilibrium and metastability in the context of Earth systems
Develop conceptual and empirical models to describe natural geochemical systems
Apply geochemical principles toward achieving a sustainable use of Earth’s resources, including predicting the impacts of resource development and developing strategies for mitigation of impacts

Field Methods in Hydrogeology Fall 2024
An introduction to the principles and theories of mineral deposit genesis.
Basic technical, economic, legal, and ethical aspects of mineral exploration and responsible development of natural resources are also covered.
View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.

Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.
Labs will be completed in groups with field data recorded in field books or datasheets.
These data will be used to a complete individual lab assignment.
This site contains over 100 groundwater monitoring wells.
Field lab activities involve:
(3) Measurement of in-situ hydraulic conductivity using single-well response tests
Each lab will provide you with a unique dataset that you will use to develop a conceptual site model of the local groundwater flow system.
• Properly construct and interpret soil core logs using United Soil Classification System, and make lithostratigraphic interpretations using geophysical logs
• Assess and interpret water level measurements through the construction of water table maps and flownets
• Interpret single-well response tests including falling and rising head (slug) tests to determine in-situ hydraulic conductivity
• Interpret hydraulic pumping tests to determine aquifer transmissivity and storage parameters and assess water resource vulnerability
Each module will contain a series of recorded lecture slides and video demonstrations reviewing core concepts and guidelines for the upcoming field lab.

topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.
To understand basic fluvial geomorphic processes and their role in landform development and change

course_name: GEOG407 - Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems (0.50)
major_name: Environmental Sciences - Water Science Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems Winter 2025
merrin.macrae@uwaterloo.ca
Email: mmacrae@uwaterloo.ca
This course focuses on ecological and biogeochemical processes that are linked to the terrestrial hydrological cycle and how these relate to the management of natural resources.

The objectives of this interdisciplinary course are to explore topics that integrate ecosystem processes with physical hydrology and examine the impacts of human activities on ecohydrological and hydrochemical processes within terrestrial systems.
Understand linkages between hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the natural environment
Understand the implications of land use change and climate change on selected ecosystems
Analyze and visualize numerical data and write laboratory reports
Jan. 14 Watershed Hydrology Field and Lab Methods for Water Quality 1 *Safety/services & orientation of labs; TAs do overview of labs
Feb. 25 Wetlands and In-stream Processes  *Data Lab Part 2
Mar. 4 Impacts of Climate Change on hydrology and biogeochem: case study of subarctic and temperate peatlands *Data Lab Part 2
Each lab section will attend a total of two “practical labs” – one will be held outdoors in the field and the other will be held indoors in a laboratory setting.
For the indoor lab, students will learn standard techniques for the processing of samples and the analyses of key water quality parameters.
This time of year can be cold and wet – students must have proper clothing to stay warm and dry for 1.5 hours in the field.
The meticulous construction of lab reports or field reports is a hallmark of any undergraduate education in geography and environmental sciences.
The careful analysis of hydrological and water quality data is also critical in water quality research and is a skill necessary to succeed in jobs in this field.

These labs will introduce you to the exploration and analysis of standard parameters in water quality analysis, by working with the data and constructing informative tables and graphs and describing what your data is showing you.
The exam will consist of a series of multiple choice, short answer and longer essay-style questions.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as understanding the importance of proper data collection and analysis, as well as the interpretation of these data.

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

As an active researcher in aquatic ecology for more than 30 years (with the Fisheries and Oceans Canada, Environment Canada, Canadian Water Network and the University of Waterloo) the instructor (Prof. Mark Servos) will highlight and demonstrate some key techniques and share experiences based on extensive field work in Canada and elsewhere.

An introduction to methods used to sample and characterize the ecological structure and function of aquatic ecosystems, including basic aspects of the abiotic environment.
Field trips to lake and stream sites are combined with laboratory analysis of samples and data.
While the main emphasis is on the techniques, the exercises also provide direct experience with some of the natural and anthropogenic variation observable in aquatic systems.
